snippet: Learning life’s lessons over great meals.
abstract: Bryan Miller describes an intimate lunch he shared with Craig Claiborne. (M)3
lead_paragraph: I CANNOT claim to have been an intimate friend of Craig Claiborne -- that fraternity could fit in a roomy banquette -- although over two decades of friendship I was the beneficiary of many quiet acts of kindness by this shy and complicated man. When I was a green freelance writer for The New York Times, for example, suddenly I became a candidate for a staff position. And I got it, only later to learn that Craig had pulled the strings. Astonishingly, after only nine months at the paper, I was offered the job of restaurant critic. Again, it was Craig working behind the scenes. And there were many more examples. I suppose the closest I came to intimacy was the day I asked him to lunch in order to elicit advice concerning the job. A little emotional back story: Craig's mansion of woes had many rooms, one of which centered on his amorous relationship with a certain retired pediatrician named Jim. Jim lived in Florida with his unsuspecting (until she suspected) wife. Consequently, the two saw each other only occasionally. This is about all I knew, or cared to know.

headline.main: Accepting a Seat at an Exclusive Table of Friends
